dir=\"auto\"\u003e🇨🇳\u003ca href=\"https://github.com/yinkaisheng/Python-UIAutomation-for-Windows/blob/master/readme_cn.md\"\u003e中文版介绍\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eDo not use 3.7.6 and 3.8.1, comtypes doesn't work in these two versions. Install an earlier version or the latest version.\n\u003ca class=\"issue-link js-issue-link\" data-error-text=\"Failed to load title\" data-id=\"564446995\" data-permission-text=\"Title is private\" data-url=\"https://github.com/enthought/comtypes/issues/202\" data-hovercard-type=\"issue\" data-hovercard-url=\"/enthought/comtypes/issues/202/hovercard\" href=\"https://github.com/enthought/comtypes/issues/202\"\u003eenthought/comtypes#202\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eThis module is for \u003ca href=\"https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/winauto/ui-automation-specification\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eUIAutomation\u003c/a\u003e on Windows(Windows XP with SP3, Windows Vista, Windows 7 and Windows 8/8.1/10).\nIt supports UIAutomation for the applications which implmented UIAutomation Provider, such as MFC, Windows Form, WPF, Modern UI(Metro UI), Qt(Partly), Firefox(\u003cstrong\u003eversion\u0026lt;=56 or \u0026gt;=60\u003c/strong\u003e), Chrome and Electron based apps(require \u003cstrong\u003e--force-renderer-accessibility\u003c/strong\u003e command line parameter).\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eI developed it in my spare time and for my personal use.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003euiautomation is shared under the Apache Licence 2.0.\u003cbr\u003e\nThis means that the code can be freely copied and distributed, and costs nothing to use.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003euiautomation1.x supports py2, py3 and doesn't depend on any third package.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003euiautomation2.0+ only supports py3 and depends on comtypes and typing(Python3.5+ built-in).\u003cbr\u003e\nuiautomation2.0+ is not backward compatible with early versions. See \u003ca href=\"https://github.com/yinkaisheng/Python-UIAutomation-for-Windows/blob/master/API%20changes.txt\"\u003eAPI changes\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eYou can install uiautomation by \"pip install uiautomation\". After installation, a automation.py that calls uiautomation will be in 'C:\\PythonXX\\Scripts'.\nYou use this script to traverse UI controls.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eRun 'C:\\PythonXX\\Scripts\\automation.py -h' for help.\u003cbr\u003e\nRun demos\\automation_calculator.py to see a simple demo.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eOn Windows 8/8.1, to automate a Metro App, the app must be in foreground. If a Metro App was switched to background, uiautomation can't fetch its controls' information.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eBy the way, You should run python as \u003cstrong\u003eadministrator\u003c/strong\u003e. Otherwise uiautomation may fail to enumerate controls or get controls' information on Windows 7 or higher.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/api/uiautomationclient/nn-uiautomationclient-iuiautomation\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eRequirements:\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eMicrosoft UIAutomation Minimum supported client:\nWindows 7, Windows Vista with SP2 and Platform Update for Windows Vista, Windows XP with SP3 and Platform Update for Windows Vista [desktop apps only]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eMicrosoft UIAutomation Minimum supported server:\nWindows Server 2008 R2, Windows Server 2008 with SP2 and Platform Update for Windows Server 2008, Windows Server 2003 with SP2 and Platform Update for Windows Server 2008 [desktop apps only]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eC++ dll source code: \u003ca href=\"https://github.com/yinkaisheng/UIAutomationClient\"\u003eUIAutomationClient\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eHow to use uiautomation?\nrun '\u003cstrong\u003eautomation.py -h\u003c/strong\u003e'\n\u003ca target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\" href=\"/yinkaisheng/Python-UIAutomation-for-Windows/blob/master/images/uiautomation-h.png\"\u003e\u003cimg src=\"/yinkaisheng/Python-UIAutomation-for-Windows/raw/master/images/uiautomation-h.png\" alt=\"help\" style=\"max-width: 100%;\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eUnderstand the arguments of automation.py, and try the following examples:\u003cbr\u003e\n\u003cstrong\u003eautomation.py -t 0 -n\u003c/strong\u003e, print current active window's controls, show fullname\u003cbr\u003e\n\u003cstrong\u003eautomation.py -r -d 1 -t 0\u003c/strong\u003e, print desktop(the root of control tree) and it's children(top level windows)\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ca target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\" href=\"/yinkaisheng/Python-UIAutomation-for-Windows/blob/master/images/automation_toplevels.png\"\u003e\u003cimg src=\"/yinkaisheng/Python-UIAutomation-for-Windows/raw/master/images/automation_toplevels.png\" alt=\"top level windows\" style=\"max-width: 100%;\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eautomation.py prints the properties of controls and the patterns they support.\nYou use controls and patterns to get controls' information and operate them.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eA control should support some patterns or conditionally supports some patterns according to its control type.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ca target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\" href=\"/yinkaisheng/Python-UIAutomation-for-Windows/blob/master/images/control_pattern.png\"\u003e\u003cimg src=\"/yinkaisheng/Python-UIAutomation-for-Windows/raw/master/images/control_pattern.png\" alt=\"patterns\" style=\"max-width: 100%;\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eRefer \u003ca href=\"https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/winauto/uiauto-controlpatternmapping\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eControl Pattern Mapping for UI Automation Clients\u003c/a\u003e for the cpmplete control pattern table.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003euiautomation searches controls from the control tree based on the controls' properties you supply.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eSuppose the control tree is\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eroot(Name='Desktop', Depth=0)\u003cbr\u003e\n　　window1(Depth=1)\u003cbr\u003e\n　　　　control1-001(Depth=2)\u003cbr\u003e\n　　　　control1-...(Depth=2)\u003cbr\u003e\n　　　　...\u003cbr\u003e\n　　　　control1-100(Depth=2)\u003cbr\u003e\n　　window2(Name='window2', Depth=1)\u003cbr\u003e\n　　　　control2-1(Depth=2)\u003cbr\u003e\n　　　　　　control2-1-001(Depth=3)\u003cbr\u003e\n　　　　　　control2-1-...(Depth=3)\u003cbr\u003e\n　　　　　　...\u003cbr\u003e\n　　　　　　control2-1-100(Depth=3)\u003cbr\u003e\n　　　　control2-2(Depth=2)\u003cbr\u003e\n　　　　control2-3(Depth=2)\u003cbr\u003e\n　　　　control2-4(Name='2-4', Depth=2)\u003cbr\u003e\n　　　　　　editcontrol(Name='myedit1', Depth=3)\u003cbr\u003e\n　　　　　　\u003cstrong\u003eeditcontrol(Name='myedit2', Depth=3)\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eIf you want to find the EditControl whose name is 'myedit2' and type 'hi',\u003cbr\u003e\nyou can write the following code:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"highlight highlight-source-python notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" dir=\"auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"uiautomation.EditControl(searchDepth=3, Name='myedit2').SendKeys('hi')\"\u003e\u003cpre\u003e\u003cspan class=\"pl-s1\"\u003euiautomation\u003c/span\u003e.\u003cspan class=\"pl-v\"\u003eEditControl\u003c/span\u003e(\u003cspan # you should find the top level window first, then find children from the top level window\n    notepadWindow = auto.WindowControl(searchDepth=1, ClassName='Notepad')\n    if not notepadWindow.Exists(3, 1):\n        print('Can not find Notepad window')\n        exit(0)\n    print(notepadWindow)\n    notepadWindow.SetTopmost(True)\n    # find the first EditControl in notepadWindow\n    edit = notepadWindow.EditControl()\n    # usually you don't need to catch exceptions\n    # but if you meet a COMError exception, put it in a try block\n    try:\n        # use value pattern to get or set value\n        edit.GetValuePattern().SetValue('Hello')# or edit.GetPattern(auto.PatternId.ValuePattern)\n    except auto.comtypes.COMError as ex:\n        # maybe you don't run python as administrator \n        # or the control doesn't have a implementation for the pattern method(I have no solution for this)\n        pass\n    edit.SendKeys('{Ctrl}{End}{Enter}World')\n    print('current text:', edit.GetValuePattern().Value)\n    # find the first TitleBarControl in notepadWindow, \n    # then find the second ButtonControl in TitleBarControl, which is the Maximize button\n    notepadWindow.TitleBarControl().ButtonControl(foundIndex=2).Click()\n    # find the first button in notepadWindow whose Name is '关闭', the close button\n    # the relative depth from Close button to Notepad window is 2\n    notepadWindow.ButtonControl(searchDepth=2, Name='关闭').Click()\n    # then notepad will popup a window askes you to save class=\"pl-en\"\u003etest\u003c/span\u003e()\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eauto.GetRootControl() returns the root control(the Desktop window)\u003cbr\u003e\nauto.WindowControl(searchDepth=1, ClassName='Notepad') creates a WindowControl, the parameters specify how to search the control\u003cbr\u003e\nthe following parameters can be used\u003cbr\u003e\nsearchFromControl = None,\u003cbr\u003e\nsearchDepth = 0xFFFFFFFF,\u003cbr\u003e\nsearchInterval = SEARCH_INTERVAL,\u003cbr\u003e\nfoundIndex = 1\u003cbr\u003e\nName\u003cbr\u003e\nSubName\u003cbr\u003e\nRegexName\u003cbr\u003e\nClassName\u003cbr\u003e\nAutomationId\u003cbr\u003e\nControlType\u003cbr\u003e\nDepth\u003cbr\u003e\nCompare\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eSee Control.__init__ for the comments of the parameters.\u003cbr\u003e\nSee scripts in folder \u003cstrong\u003edemos\u003c/strong\u003e for more examples.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eControl.Element returns the low level COM object \u003ca href=\"https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/api/uiautomationclient/nn-uiautomationclient-iuiautomationelement\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eIUIAutomationElement\u003c/a\u003e,\nAlmost all methods and properties of Control are implemented via IUIAutomationElement COM API and Win32 API.\nwhen calling a control's method or property that indirectly calls Control.Element and Control.Element is None,\nuiautomation starts to search the control by the properties you supply.\nuiautomation will raise a LookupError exception if it can't find the control in uiautomation.TIME_OUT_SECOND(default 10 seconds).\nControl.Element will has a valid value if uiautomation finds the control successfully.\nYou can use Control.Exists(maxSearchSeconds, searchIntervalSeconds) to check whether a control Exists, this function doesn't raise any exception.\nCall Control.Refind or Control.Exists to make Control.Element invalid again and uiautomation will starts a new search.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eFor example:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"highlight highlight-source-python notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" dir=\"auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"#!python3\n# -*- coding:utf-8 -*-\n# this script only works with Win32 notepad.exe\n# if you notepad.exe is the Windows Store version in Windows 11, you need to uninstall it.\nimport subprocess\nimport uiautomation as auto\nauto.uiautomation.SetGlobalSearchTimeout(15)  # set new timeout 15\n\n\ndef main():\n    subprocess.Popen('notepad.exe', shell=True)\n    window = auto.WindowControl(searchDepth=1, ClassName='Notepad')\n    # or use Compare for custom search\n    # window = auto.WindowControl(searchDepth=1, ClassName='Notepad', Compare=lambda control,depth:control.ProcessId==100)\n    edit = window.EditControl()\n    # when calling SendKeys, uiautomation starts to search window and edit in 15 seconds\n    # because SendKeys indirectly calls Control.Element and Control.Element is None\n    # if window and edit don't exist in 15 seconds, a LookupError exception will be raised\n    try:\n        edit.SendKeys('first notepad')\n    except LookupError as ex:\n        print(\u0026quot;The first notepad doesn't exist in 15 seconds\u0026quot;)\n        return\n    # the second call to SendKeys doesn't trigger a search, the previous call makes sure that Control.Element is valid\n    edit.SendKeys('{Ctrl}a{Del}')\n    window.GetWindowPattern().Close()  # close the dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eIf automation.py can't print the controls you see.\nMaybe the controls were built by DirectUI(or CustomControl), not UI Frameworks supplied by Microsoft.\nIn order to support UIAutomation, an UI Framework must implement \u003ca href=\"https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/winauto/uiauto-providersoverview\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eUI Automation Provider\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eA Microsoft UI Automation provider is a software object that exposes an element of an application's UI so that accessibility client applications can retrieve information about the element and invoke its functionality. In general, each control or other distinct element in a UI has a provider.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eMicrosoft includes a provider for each of the standard controls that are supplied with Microsoft Win32, Windows Forms, and Windows Presentation Foundation (WPF). This means that the standard controls are automatically exposed to UI Automation clients; you do not need to implement any accessibility interfaces for the standard controls.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eIf your application includes any custom controls, you need to implement UI Automation providers for those controls to make them accessible to accessibility client applications. You also need to implement providers for any third party controls that do not include a provider. You implement a provider by implementing UI Automation provider interfaces and control pattern interfaces.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eAnother UI tool \u003ca href=\"https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/winauto/inspect-objects\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eInspect.exe\u003c/a\u003e supplied by Microsoft can also be used to traverse the UI elements. It has an UI interface while my script shows UI elements in terminal.\nBut I found that my script is more convenient sometimes.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ca target=\"_blank\" data-hpc="true"><article class="markdown-body entry-content container-lg" itemprop="text"><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h1 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">The uiautomation module</h1><a id="user-content-the-uiautomation-module" class="anchor" aria-label="Permalink: The uiautomation module" href="#the-uiautomation-module"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div><p dir="auto">🇨🇳<a href="https://github.com/yinkaisheng/Python-UIAutomation-for-Windows/blob/master/readme_cn.md">中文版介绍</a></p><p dir="auto">Do not use 3.7.6 and 3.8.1, comtypes doesn't work in these two versions. Install an earlier version or the latest version.<a class="issue-link js-issue-link" data-error-text="Failed to load title" data-id="564446995" data-permission-text="Title is private" data-url="https://github.com/enthought/comtypes/issues/202" data-hovercard-type="issue" data-hovercard-url="/enthought/comtypes/issues/202/hovercard" href="https://github.com/enthought/comtypes/issues/202">enthought/comtypes#202</a></p><p dir="auto">This module is for <a href="https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/winauto/ui-automation-specification" rel="nofollow">UIAutomation</a> on Windows(Windows XP with SP3, Windows Vista, Windows 7 and Windows 8/8.1/10).It supports UIAutomation for the applications which implmented UIAutomation Provider, such as MFC, Windows Form, WPF, Modern UI(Metro UI), Qt(Partly), Firefox(<strong>version<=56 or >=60</strong>), Chrome and Electron based apps(require <strong>--force-renderer-accessibility</strong> command line parameter).</p><p dir="auto">I developed it in my spare time and for my personal use.</p><p dir="auto">uiautomation is shared under the Apache Licence 2.0.<br>This means that the code can be freely copied and distributed, and costs nothing to use.</p><p dir="auto">uiautomation1.x supports py2, py3 and doesn't depend on any third package.</p><p dir="auto">uiautomation2.0+ only supports py3 and depends on comtypes and typing(Python3.5+ built-in).<br>uiautomation2.0+ is not backward compatible with early versions. See <a href="https://github.com/yinkaisheng/Python-UIAutomation-for-Windows/blob/master/API%20changes.txt">API changes</a>.</p><p dir="auto">You can install uiautomation by "pip install uiautomation". After installation, a automation.py that calls uiautomation will be in 'C:\PythonXX\Scripts'.You use this script to traverse UI controls.</p><p dir="auto">Run 'C:\PythonXX\Scripts\automation.py -h' for help.<br>Run demos\automation_calculator.py to see a simple demo.</p><p dir="auto">On Windows 8/8.1, to automate a Metro App, the app must be in foreground. If a Metro App was switched to background, uiautomation can't fetch its controls' information.</p><p dir="auto">By the way, You should run python as <strong>administrator</strong>. Otherwise uiautomation may fail to enumerate controls or get controls' information on Windows 7 or higher.</p><p dir="auto"><a href="https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/api/uiautomationclient/nn-uiautomationclient-iuiautomation" rel="nofollow">Requirements:</a></p><p dir="auto">Microsoft UIAutomation Minimum supported client:Windows 7, Windows Vista with SP2 and Platform Update for Windows Vista, Windows XP with SP3 and Platform Update for Windows Vista [desktop apps only]</p><p dir="auto">Microsoft UIAutomation Minimum supported server:Windows Server 2008 R2, Windows Server 2008 with SP2 and Platform Update for Windows Server 2008, Windows Server 2003 with SP2 and Platform Update for Windows Server 2008 [desktop apps only]</p><p dir="auto">C++ dll source code: <a href="https://github.com/yinkaisheng/UIAutomationClient">UIAutomationClient</a></p><hr><p dir="auto">How to use uiautomation?run '<strong>automation.py -h</strong>'<a target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer" href="/yinkaisheng/Python-UIAutomation-for-Windows/blob/master/images/uiautomation-h.png"><img src="/yinkaisheng/Python-UIAutomation-for-Windows/raw/master/images/uiautomation-h.png" alt="help" style="max-width: 100%;"></a></p><p dir="auto">Understand the arguments of automation.py, and try the following examples:<br><strong>automation.py -t 0 -n</strong>, print current active window's controls, show fullname<br><strong>automation.py -r -d 1 -t 0</strong>, print desktop(the root of control tree) and it's children(top level windows)</p><p dir="auto"><a target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer" href="/yinkaisheng/Python-UIAutomation-for-Windows/blob/master/images/automation_toplevels.png"><img src="/yinkaisheng/Python-UIAutomation-for-Windows/raw/master/images/automation_toplevels.png" alt="top level windows" style="max-width: 100%;"></a></p><p dir="auto">automation.py prints the properties of controls and the patterns they support.You use controls and patterns to get controls' information and operate them.</p><p dir="auto">A control should support some patterns or conditionally supports some patterns according to its control type.</p><p dir="auto"><a target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer" href="/yinkaisheng/Python-UIAutomation-for-Windows/blob/master/images/control_pattern.png"><img src="/yinkaisheng/Python-UIAutomation-for-Windows/raw/master/images/control_pattern.png" alt="patterns" style="max-width: 100%;"></a></p><p dir="auto">Refer <a href="https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/winauto/uiauto-controlpatternmapping" rel="nofollow">Control Pattern Mapping for UI Automation Clients</a> for the cpmplete control pattern table.</p><p dir="auto">uiautomation searches controls from the control tree based on the controls' properties you supply.</p><p dir="auto">Suppose the control tree is</p><p dir="auto">root(Name='Desktop', Depth=0)<br>　　window1(Depth=1)<br>　　　　control1-001(Depth=2)<br>　　　　control1-...(Depth=2)<br>　　　　...<br>　　　　control1-100(Depth=2)<br>　　window2(Name='window2', Depth=1)<br>　　　　control2-1(Depth=2)<br>　　　　　　control2-1-001(Depth=3)<br>　　　　　　control2-1-...(Depth=3)<br>　　　　　　...<br>　　　　　　control2-1-100(Depth=3)<br>　　　　control2-2(Depth=2)<br>　　　　control2-3(Depth=2)<br>　　　　control2-4(Name='2-4', Depth=2)<br>　　　　　　editcontrol(Name='myedit1', Depth=3)<br>　　　　　　<strong>editcontrol(Name='myedit2', Depth=3)</strong></p><p dir="auto">If you want to find the EditControl whose name is 'myedit2' and type 'hi',<br>you can write the following code:</p><div class="highlight highlight-source-python notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="uiautomation.EditControl(searchDepth=3, Name='myedit2').SendKeys('hi')"><pre><span class="pl-s1">uiautomation</span>.<span class="pl-v">EditControl</span>(<span class="pl-s1">searchDepth</span><span class="pl-c1">=</span><span class="pl-c1">3</span>, <span class="pl-v">Name</span><span class="pl-c1">=</span><span class="pl-s">'myedit2'</span>).<span class="pl-v">SendKeys</span>(<span class="pl-s">'hi'</span>)</pre></div><p dir="auto">But this code run slowly because there are more than 200 controls before myedit2 in the control tree.<br>uiautomation has to traverse more than 200 controls before finding myedit2 if search from root in 3 search depth.<br>The better is:</p><div class="highlight highlight-source-python notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="window2 = uiautomation.WindowControl(searchDepth=1, Name='window2') # search 2 timessub = window2.Control(searchDepth=1, Name='2-4')    # search 4 timesedit = sub.EditControl(searchDepth=1, Name='myedit2')   # search 2 timesedit.SendKeys('hi')"><pre><span class="pl-s1">window2</span> <span class="pl-c1">=</span> <span class="pl-s1">uiautomation</span>.<span class="pl-v">WindowControl</span>(<span class="pl-s1">searchDepth</span><span class="pl-c1">=</span><span class="pl-c1">1</span>, <span class="pl-v">Name</span><span class="pl-c1">=</span><span class="pl-s">'window2'</span>) <span class="pl-c"># search 2 times</span><span class="pl-s1">sub</span> <span class="pl-c1">=</span> <span class="pl-s1">window2</span>.<span class="pl-v">Control</span>(<span class="pl-s1">searchDepth</span><span class="pl-c1">=</span><span class="pl-c1">1</span>, <span class="pl-v">Name</span><span class="pl-c1">=</span><span class="pl-s">'2-4'</span>)    <span class="pl-c"># search 4 times</span><span class="pl-s1">edit</span> <span class="pl-c1">=</span> <span class="pl-s1">sub</span>.<span ButtonControl    ClassName:     Depth: 4<br>　　　　　　ControlType: ThumbControl    ClassName:     Depth: 3<br>　　　　ControlType: TitleBarControl    ClassName:     Depth: 2<br>　　　　　　ControlType: MenuBarControl    ClassName:     Depth: 3<br>　　　　　　　　ControlType: MenuItemControl    ClassName:     Depth: 4<br>　　　　　　ControlType: ButtonControl    ClassName:     Name: 最小化    Depth: 3    <strong>(Minimize Button)</strong><br>　　　　　　ControlType: ButtonControl    ClassName:     Name: 最大化    Depth: 3    <strong>(Maximize Button)</strong><br>　　　　　　ControlType: ButtonControl    ClassName: dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="# -*- coding: utf-8 -*-# this script only works with Win32 notepad.exe# if you notepad.exe is the Windows Store version in Windows 11, you need to uninstall it.import subprocessimport uiautomation as autodef test():    print(auto.GetRootControl())    subprocess.Popen('notepad.exe', shell=True)    # you should find the top level window first, then find children from the top level window    notepadWindow = auto.WindowControl(searchDepth=1, ClassName='Notepad')    if not notepadWindow.Exists(3, 1):        print('Can not find Notepad window')        exit(0)    print(notepadWindow)    notepadWindow.SetTopmost(True)    # find the first EditControl in notepadWindow    edit = notepadWindow.EditControl()    # usually you don't need to catch exceptions    # but if you meet a COMError exception, put it in a try block    try:        # use value pattern to get or set value        edit.GetValuePattern().SetValue('Hello')# or edit.GetPattern(auto.PatternId.ValuePattern)    except auto.comtypes.COMError as ex:        # maybe you don't run python as administrator         # or the control doesn't have a implementation for the pattern method(I have no solution for this)        pass    edit.SendKeys('{Ctrl}{End}{Enter}World')    print('current text:', edit.GetValuePattern().Value)    # find the first TitleBarControl in notepadWindow,     # then find the second ButtonControl in TitleBarControl, which is the Maximize button    notepadWindow.TitleBarControl().ButtonControl(foundIndex=2).Click()    # find the first button in notepadWindow whose Name is '关闭', the close button    # the relative depth from Close button to Notepad window is 2    notepadWindow.ButtonControl(searchDepth=2, Name='关闭').Click()    # then notepad will popup a window askes you to save or not, press hotkey alt+n not to save    auto.SendKeys('{Alt}n')if __name__ == '__main__':    test()"><pre><span class="pl-c"># -*- coding: utf-8 control(the Desktop window)<br>auto.WindowControl(searchDepth=1, ClassName='Notepad') creates a WindowControl, the parameters specify how to search the control<br>the following parameters can be used<br>searchFromControl = None,<br>searchDepth = 0xFFFFFFFF,<br>searchInterval = SEARCH_INTERVAL,<br>foundIndex = 1<br>Name<br>SubName<br>RegexName<br>ClassName<br>AutomationId<br>ControlType<br>Depth<br>Compare</p><p dir="auto">See Control.__init__ for the comments of the parameters.<br>See scripts in folder <strong>demos</strong> for more examples.</p><p dir="auto">Control.Element returns the low level COM object <a href="https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/api/uiautomationclient/nn-uiautomationclient-iuiautomationelement" rel="nofollow">IUIAutomationElement</a>,Almost all methods and properties of Control are implemented via IUIAutomationElement COM API and Win32 API.when calling a control's method or property that indirectly calls Control.Element and Control.Element is None,uiautomation starts to search the control by the properties you supply.uiautomation will raise a LookupError exception if it can't find the control in uiautomation.TIME_OUT_SECOND(default 10 seconds).Control.Element will has a valid value if uiautomation finds the control successfully.You can use Control.Exists(maxSearchSeconds, searchIntervalSeconds) to check whether a control Exists, this function doesn't raise any exception.Call Control.Refind or Control.Exists to make Control.Element invalid again and uiautomation will starts a new search.</p><p dir="auto">For example:</p><div class="highlight highlight-source-python notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="#!python3# -*- coding:utf-8 -*-# this script only works with Win32 notepad.exe# if you notepad.exe is the Windows Store version in Windows 11, you need to uninstall it.import subprocessimport uiautomation as autoauto.uiautomation.SetGlobalSearchTimeout(15)  # set new timeout 15def main():    subprocess.Popen('notepad.exe', shell=True)    window = auto.WindowControl(searchDepth=1, ClassName='Notepad')    # or use Compare for custom search    # window = auto.WindowControl(searchDepth=1, ClassName='Notepad', Compare=lambda control,depth:control.ProcessId==100)    edit = window.EditControl()    # when calling SendKeys, uiautomation starts to search window and edit in 15 seconds    # because SendKeys indirectly calls Control.Element and Control.Element is None    # if window and edit don't exist in 15 seconds, a LookupError exception will be raised    try:        edit.SendKeys('first notepad')    except LookupError as ex:        print("The first notepad doesn't exist in 15 seconds")        return    # the second call to SendKeys doesn't trigger a search, the previous call makes sure that Control.Element is valid    edit.SendKeys('{Ctrl}a{Del}')    window.GetWindowPattern().Close()  # close the first Notepad, window and edit become invalid even though their Elements have a value    subprocess.Popen('notepad.exe')  # run second Notepad    window.Refind()  # need to refind window, trigger a new search    edit.Refind()  # need to refind edit, trigger a new search    edit.SendKeys('second notepad')    edit.SendKeys('{Ctrl}a{Del}')    window.GetWindowPattern().Close()  # close the second Notepad, window and edit become invalid again    subprocess.Popen('notepad.exe')  # run third Notepad    if window.Exists(3, 1): # trigger a new search        if edit.Exists(3):  # trigger a new search            edit.SendKeys('third notepad')  # edit.Exists makes sure that edit.Element has a valid value now            edit.SendKeys('{Ctrl}a{Del}')        window.GetWindowPattern().Close()    else:        print("The third notepad doesn't exist in 3 seconds")if __name__ == '__main__':    main()"><pre><span class="pl-c">#!python3</span><span class="pl-c"># -*- coding:utf-8 -*-</span><span class="pl-c"># this script only works <span class="pl-s">'__main__'</span>:    <span class="pl-en">main</span>()</pre></div><hr><p dir="auto"><strong>If automation.py can't print the controls you see.Maybe the controls were built by DirectUI(or CustomControl), not UI Frameworks supplied by Microsoft.In order to support UIAutomation, an UI Framework must implement <a href="https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/winauto/uiauto-providersoverview" rel="nofollow">UI Automation Provider</a>.</strong></p><p dir="auto">A Microsoft UI Automation provider is a software object that exposes an element of an application's UI so that accessibility client applications can retrieve information about the element and invoke its functionality. In general, each control or other distinct element in a UI has a provider.</p><p dir="auto">Microsoft includes a provider for each of the standard controls that are supplied with Microsoft Win32, Windows Forms, and Windows Presentation Foundation (WPF). This means that the standard controls are automatically exposed to UI Automation clients; you do not need to implement any accessibility interfaces for the standard controls.</p><p dir="auto">If your application includes any custom controls, you need to implement UI Automation providers for those controls to make them accessible to accessibility client applications. You also need to implement providers for any third party controls that do not include a provider. You implement a provider by implementing UI Automation provider interfaces and control pattern interfaces.</p><hr><p dir="auto">Another UI tool <a href="https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/winauto/inspect-objects" rel="nofollow">Inspect.exe</a> supplied by Microsoft can also be used to traverse the UI elements. It has an UI interface while my script shows UI elements in terminal.But I found that my script is more convenient sometimes.</p><p dir="auto"><a target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer nofollow"
